org.jooby.handlers

Class CsrfHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jooby.handlers.CsrfHandler
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Route.Filter

    public class CsrfHandler
extends Object
implements Route.Filter

    Cross Site Request Forgery handler

     {
   use("*", new CsrfHandler());
 }

    This filter require a token on POST, PUT, PATCH and DELETE requests. A custom policy might be provided via: requireTokenOn(Predicate).

    Default token generator, use a UUID.randomUUID(). A custom token generator might be provided via: tokenGen(Function).

    Default token name is: csrf. If you want to use a different name, just pass the name to the CsrfHandler(String) constructor.

    Token verification

    The CsrfHandler handler will read an existing token from Session (or created a new one is necessary) and make available as a request local variable via: Request.set(String, Object).

    If the incoming request require a token verification, it will extract the token from:

    1. HTTP header
    2. HTTP parameter

    If the extracted token doesn't match the existing token (from Session) a 403 will be thrown.

    Since:
    0.8.1
    Author:
    edgar

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      CsrfHandler()
      Creates a new CsrfHandler and use csrf as token name.

      Creates a new CsrfHandler handler and use the given name to save the token in the Session and or extract the token from incoming requests.

        public CsrfHandler requireTokenOn(Predicate<Request> requireToken)

        Returns:

      • handle

        public void handle(Request req,
                   Response rsp,
                   Route.Chain chain)
            throws Throwable
        Description copied from interface: Route.Filter
        The handle method of the Filter is called by the server each time a request/response pair is passed through the chain due to a client request for a resource at the end of the chain. The Route.Chain passed in to this method allows the Filter to pass on the request and response to the next entity in the chain.

        A typical implementation of this method would follow the following pattern:

        • Examine the request
        • Optionally wrap the request object with a custom implementation to filter content or headers for input filtering
        • Optionally wrap the response object with a custom implementation to filter content or headers for output filtering
          • Either invoke the next entity in the chain using the Route.Chain object (chain.next(req, rsp)),
          • or not pass on the request/response pair to the next entity in the filter chain to block the request processing
        • Directly set headers on the response after invocation of the next entity in the filter chain.
        Specified by:
        handle in interface Route.Filter
        Parameters:
        req - A HTTP request.
        rsp - A HTTP response.
        chain - A route chain.
        Throws:
        Throwable - If something goes wrong.
